column2: That Lincoln was one of the greatest men of all time and belongs to eternity, was realized then, but is still more deeply realized now.
column3: That Lincoln was one of the greatest men of all time and belongs to eternity, was realized then, but is still more deeply realized now.

column2: His wonderful name has become a household word, not only in the United States but everywhere.
column3: His wonderful name has become a household word, not only in the United States but everywhere.

column2: And as the mist of the confusing events that surrounded him is clearing away in the light of history, his form is becoming mightier and more venerable every day.
column3: And as the mist of the confusing events that surrounded him is clearing away in the light of history, his form is becoming mightier and more venerable every day.

column2: CHAPTER XXIV
column3: CHAPTER twenty four

column2: GRACE DARLING
column3: GRACE DARLING

column2: The coast of Northumberland in England is rocky and severe with lofty flint-ledged cliffs where great waves thunder, hurling the white foam high into the air.
column3: The coast of Northumberland in England is rocky and severe with lofty flint ledged cliffs where great waves thunder, hurling the white foam high into the air.

column2: It is a coast that is feared by vessels and many wrecks have taken place there.
column3: It is a coast that is feared by vessels and many wrecks have taken place there.

column2: As is usual in such a locality it is the home of brave fishermen and daring boatmen who have many thrilling rescues to remember and many stormy encounters with the utmost fury of the sea.
column3: As is usual in such a locality it is the home of brave fishermen and daring boatmen who have many thrilling rescues to remember and many stormy encounters with the utmost fury of the sea.

column2: But of all the tales of daring that are talked of by the fisher folk, the bravest of all was performed by a girl whose name was Grace Darling,--a name that now is known not only in the places where she lived but all over the world.
column3: But of all the tales of daring that are talked of by the fisher folk, the bravest of all was performed by a girl whose name was Grace Darling,--a name that now is known not only in the places where she lived but all over the world.

column2: Grace Horsley Darling was the daughter of a lighthouse keeper named William Darling, who tended a light on one of the Farne Islands as his father had done before him.
column3: Grace Horsley Darling was the daughter of a lighthouse keeper named William Darling, who tended a light on one of the Farne Islands as his father had done before him.

column2: Grace, who was the seventh of nine children, was born in 1815, in Bamborough, and when she was a little girl of eleven years her father was given charge of the new light on Longstone Rock, which was one of a series of dangerous reefs where no vessel ever built could live when a gale was blowing.
column3: Grace, who was the seventh of nine children, was born in eighteen fifteen, in Bamborough, and when she was a little girl of eleven years her father was given charge of the new light on Longstone Rock, which was one of a series of dangerous reefs where no vessel ever built could live when a gale was blowing.

column2: The highest part of Longstone Rock was only four feet above the surface of the sea, and near at hand were twenty-three other reefs or islands, between which the ocean tides ran in curious currents and eddys, and where the great rollers came racing in with a tremendous roaring to burst upon the base of the lighthouse and throw the spray high above the light itself.
column3: The highest part of Longstone Rock was only four feet above the surface of the sea, and near at hand were twenty three other reefs or islands, between which the ocean tides ran in curious currents and eddys, and where the great rollers came racing in with a tremendous roaring to burst upon the base of the lighthouse and throw the spray high above the light itself.

column2: It was a wild spot, even in calm weather, but when a storm blew it became terrible.
column3: It was a wild spot, even in calm weather, but when a storm blew it became terrible.

column2: Then all communication with the mainland was cut off, and for days at a time the only news that the outside world had from the lonely lighthouse keeper was the yellow beam of the lantern that shone from the top of the tower across the desolate expanse of ugly rocks and roaring waters, where any ship that chanced to be entrapped was caught in the grip of strange currents and pounded into matchwood by the breakers.
column3: Then all communication with the mainland was cut off, and for days at a time the only news that the outside world had from the lonely lighthouse keeper was the yellow beam of the lantern that shone from the top of the tower across the desolate expanse of ugly rocks and roaring waters, where any ship that chanced to be entrapped was caught in the grip of strange currents and pounded into matchwood by the breakers.

column2: Grace did not find the life at the lighthouse unpleasant.
column3: Grace did not find the life at the lighthouse unpleasant.

column2: Her father was an intelligent and kind-hearted man who gave an eye to her education himself, and taught her how to read and write.
column3: Her father was an intelligent and kind hearted man who gave an eye to her education himself, and taught her how to read and write.

column2: He was also considered the best boatman on the whole Northumberland coast--the bravest and most skilful, and it was partly due to his reputation in these respects that he was made the keeper of the new light on the Longstone with a large increase in pay and a comfortable home for his family--for the interior of the lighthouse held several large and pleasant rooms where the Darlings lived.
column3: He was also considered the best boatman on the whole Northumberland coast-the bravest and most skilful, and it was partly due to his reputation in these respects that he was made the keeper of the new light on the Longstone with a large increase in pay and a comfortable home for his family-for the interior of the lighthouse held several large and pleasant rooms where the Darlings lived.

column2: All of his elder children had gone off to make their living, and William Darling lived with his wife and his daughter Grace, who spent her time in reading, helping her mother with the housework, and, when it was calm, wandering over the rocks observing the gulls, the sea weeds and the strange sea creatures that the ocean brought to the surface or that crawled and swam among the more sheltered rock pools.
column3: All of his elder children had gone off to make their living, and William Darling lived with his wife and his daughter Grace, who spent her time in reading, helping her mother with the housework, and, when it was calm, wandering over the rocks observing the gulls, the sea weeds and the strange sea creatures that the ocean brought to the surface or that crawled and swam among the more sheltered rock pools.

column2: But the confinement of the life in the lighthouse was not good for the growing girl, and Grace never was strong and robust as would be expected from the daughter of fishermen.
column3: But the confinement of the life in the lighthouse was not good for the growing girl, and Grace never was strong and robust as would be expected from the daughter of fishermen.

column2: Nor was she handsome.
column3: Nor was she handsome.

column2: But she possessed a kindly and winning nature, and, as will be seen, the ability to rise to heights of greatness when necessity called on her to do so.
column3: But she possessed a kindly and winning nature, and, as will be seen, the ability to rise to heights of greatness when necessity called on her to do so.

column2: When Grace was a young woman of twenty-three a terrible storm burst suddenly upon the coast and in the twinkling of an eye the reefs about the lighthouse were a sea of churning foam, while the great waves racing in from the ocean thundered so mightily at its base that it seemed as though they must tear it from its foundations and sweep it away.
column3: When Grace was a young woman of twenty three a terrible storm burst suddenly upon the coast and in the twinkling of an eye the reefs about the lighthouse were a sea of churning foam, while the great waves racing in from the ocean thundered so mightily at its base that it seemed as though they must tear it from its foundations and sweep it away.

column2: A short time before this gale broke, the steamer _Forfarshire_ had sailed from Hull for Dundee in Scotland.
column3: A short time before this gale broke, the steamer underscore Forfarshire underscore had sailed from Hull for Dundee in Scotland.

column2: She was commanded by a captain named John Humble and had aboard all told about sixty-three persons, including the passengers and crew.
column3: She was commanded by a captain named john Humble and had aboard all told about sixty three persons, including the passengers and crew.

column2: She was a fine new steamer, well and strongly built, but she had put to sea with her boilers in poor condition, and it had been intended to give them a thorough overhauling in Dundee.
column3: She was a fine new steamer, well and strongly built, but she had put to sea with her boilers in poor condition, and it had been intended to give them a thorough overhauling in Dundee.

column2: When the steamer was off Flamborough Head the boilers commenced to leak, and the ship's fires were extinguished.
column3: When the steamer was off Flamborough Head the boilers commenced to leak, and the ship's fires were extinguished.

column2: They were rekindled and the leak repaired, but just as the _Forfarshire_ was off the Farne Islands the gale broke with great fury.
column3: They were rekindled and the leak repaired, but just as the underscore Forfarshire underscore was off the Farne Islands the gale broke with great fury.

column2: While pitching in the heavy seas the boilers leaked terribly, the fires were again put out and the ship became unmanageable.
column3: While pitching in the heavy seas the boilers leaked terribly, the fires were again put out and the ship became unmanageable.

column2: Sails were hoisted, but were torn to ribbons by the wind.
column3: Sails were hoisted, but were torn to ribbons by the wind.

column2: With no propelling power the _Forfarshire_ rolled helpless in the trough of the sea, and was swiftly borne toward the rocks.
column3: With no propelling power the underscore Forfarshire underscore rolled helpless in the trough of the sea, and was swiftly borne toward the rocks.

column2: Fog and rain made it impossible for the sailors to see until they were in the teeth of the breakers, and then the beam of the lighthouse showed them the wild rocks only a short distance away.
column3: Fog and rain made it impossible for the sailors to see until they were in the teeth of the breakers, and then the beam of the lighthouse showed them the wild rocks only a short distance away.

column2: Nothing could save them from destruction.
column3: Nothing could save them from destruction.

column2: With a crash the steamer drove on the Harcars rocks and remained there, the seas breaking completely over it.
column3: With a crash the steamer drove on the Harcars rocks and remained there, the seas breaking completely over it.

column2: Some of the crew launched a boat and escaped, deserting their captain, the passengers and the ship.
column3: Some of the crew launched a boat and escaped, deserting their captain, the passengers and the ship.

column2: The rest clung to what supports they could find and held on expecting instant death.
column3: The rest clung to what supports they could find and held on expecting instant death.

column2: A wave, larger than the rest, picked up the _Forfarshire_ bodily and drove it down again upon the rocks, breaking it in two.
column3: A wave, larger than the rest, picked up the underscore Forfarshire underscore bodily and drove it down again upon the rocks, breaking it in two.

column2: The after half of the vessel was swept away by the seas with many passengers and the captain and his wife.
column3: The after half of the vessel was swept away by the seas with many passengers and the captain and his wife.

column2: All were lost.
column3: All were lost.

column2: On the forward part of the ship about twelve wretched persons remained in most desperate plight, the seas breaking over them and threatening to engulf the remaining portion of the vessel.
column3: On the forward part of the ship about twelve wretched persons remained in most desperate plight, the seas breaking over them and threatening to engulf the remaining portion of the vessel.

column2: When day broke the wreck could be seen from the mainland, but the misery of the unfortunate persons who survived was even more plain to William Darling and his family.
column3: When day broke the wreck could be seen from the mainland, but the misery of the unfortunate persons who survived was even more plain to William Darling and his family.

column2: Grace begged her father to launch a boat and go to their assistance, but Darling, brave sailor as he was, knew that there was little or no chance of his ever reaching the doomed ship, and shook his head.
column3: Grace begged her father to launch a boat and go to their assistance, but Darling, brave sailor as he was, knew that there was little or no chance of his ever reaching the doomed ship, and shook his head.

column2: Then Grace began to plead with her father, telling him it would be better for him to lose his life than to pass by people in such distress, and that she herself would go with him and bear a hand at the oars.
column3: Then Grace began to plead with her father, telling him it would be better for him to lose his life than to pass by people in such distress, and that she herself would go with him and bear a hand at the oars.

column2: Darling was no coward, and the prayers and entreaties of his daughter won the day.
column3: Darling was no coward, and the prayers and entreaties of his daughter won the day.

column2: He decided to risk launching a boat from the lighthouse.
column3: He decided to risk launching a boat from the lighthouse.

column2: With Mrs. Darling to help them in launching their boat, Grace and her father put forth from the lighthouse, running their boat into the sea in the lee of the rocks, and pulling strongly for the wreck.
column3: With mrs Darling to help them in launching their boat, Grace and her father put forth from the lighthouse, running their boat into the sea in the lee of the rocks, and pulling strongly for the wreck.

column2: Father and daughter both labored at the oars, unable to speak on account of the roar of the sea and wind, and blinded by the spray that whirled over them.
column3: Father and daughter both labored at the oars, unable to speak on account of the roar of the sea and wind, and blinded by the spray that whirled over them.

column2: Their boat was tossed like a shuttlecock in the great waves, and they knew that unless the shipwrecked persons could aid them it would be impossible to return to the lighthouse.
column3: Their boat was tossed like a shuttlecock in the great waves, and they knew that unless the shipwrecked persons could aid them it would be impossible to return to the lighthouse.

column2: They must succeed or die, and their chance of success was small.
column3: They must succeed or die, and their chance of success was small.

column2: Little by little they drew near the wreck.
column3: Little by little they drew near the wreck.

column2: By this time the tide had ebbed sufficiently for the survivors to leave the ship and stand on the slippery rocks, but already some of them had succumbed and the rest would certainly be washed away and drowned at returning high water.
column3: By this time the tide had ebbed sufficiently for the survivors to leave the ship and stand on the slippery rocks, but already some of them had succumbed and the rest would certainly be washed away and drowned at returning high water.

column2: As the rescuers drew near the reef, Darling leaped ashore, and Grace kept the frail rowboat from dashing itself to pieces against the rocks.
column3: As the rescuers drew near the reef, Darling leaped ashore, and Grace kept the frail rowboat from dashing itself to pieces against the rocks.

column2: Then followed the difficult task of getting the survivors into the boat.
column3: Then followed the difficult task of getting the survivors into the boat.

column2: One after one waded out as far as he dared and was pulled over the gunwale.
column3: One after one waded out as far as he dared and was pulled over the gunwale.

column2: When the last person was aboard Darling clambered back, and with new hands at the oars the boat was rowed back to the lighthouse--a trip that required great strength and much time for the current was against them.
column3: When the last person was aboard Darling clambered back, and with new hands at the oars the boat was rowed back to the lighthouse-a trip that required great strength and much time for the current was against them.

column2: And when the light was reached, the shipwrecked people were soon made comfortable and cared for by Grace and Mrs. Darling, and nine lives were thus saved by the determination of a single girl.
column3: And when the light was reached, the shipwrecked people were soon made comfortable and cared for by Grace and mrs Darling, and nine lives were thus saved by the determination of a single girl.

column2: In the meantime, and after the gale had abated considerably, a boat full of fishermen put out from the shore at a place called North Sunderland and after nearly being swamped in the high seas succeeded in drawing near the wreck.
column3: In the meantime, and after the gale had abated considerably, a boat full of fishermen put out from the shore at a place called North Sunderland and after nearly being swamped in the high seas succeeded in drawing near the wreck.

column2: They saw there was no living thing left aboard, and not daring to return to the mainland in the sea then running succeeded in reaching the lighthouse.
column3: They saw there was no living thing left aboard, and not daring to return to the mainland in the sea then running succeeded in reaching the lighthouse.

column2: Among them was Grace's brother, Brooks Darling, and the heroism of his achievement and that of the other fishermen was only exceeded by the marvelous feat of the girl herself and of her father.
column3: Among them was Grace's brother, Brooks Darling, and the heroism of his achievement and that of the other fishermen was only exceeded by the marvelous feat of the girl herself and of her father.

column2: In the course of a few days the fishermen succeeded in returning to the shore, taking with them the news.
column3: In the course of a few days the fishermen succeeded in returning to the shore, taking with them the news.

column2: All England rang with the fame of Grace's exploit, and letters and gifts poured in from every side.
column3: All England rang with the fame of Grace's exploit, and letters and gifts poured in from every side.

column2: Scores of people visited the lighthouse.
column3: Scores of people visited the lighthouse.

column2: Grace was feted and admired, and a public subscription in her benefit resulted in a gift of seven hundred pounds, or about thirty-five hundred dollars of our money.
column3: Grace was feted and admired, and a public subscription in her benefit resulted in a gift of seven hundred pounds, or about thirty five hundred dollars of our money.

column2: She also received four medals, and a large sum of money in private gifts.
column3: She also received four medals, and a large sum of money in private gifts.

column2: Grace and her family took their new prominence with great good sense and modesty, and disliked the publicity which came to them.
column3: Grace and her family took their new prominence with great good sense and modesty, and disliked the publicity which came to them.

column2: They were astonished at the commotion their exploit had caused, for to them it appeared little more than a part of the day's work that duty required them to perform.
column3: They were astonished at the commotion their exploit had caused, for to them it appeared little more than a part of the day's work that duty required them to perform.

column2: But Grace did not live long after her exploit.
column3: But Grace did not live long after her exploit.

column2: Her confined life at the lighthouse and the exposure she underwent there resulted in the disease of consumption from which she rapidly wasted away.
column3: Her confined life at the lighthouse and the exposure she underwent there resulted in the disease of consumption from which she rapidly wasted away.

column2: In spite of the best medical aid she steadily drooped, and two years after she had done her brave deed she died in the town of Bamborough where she had been born.
column3: In spite of the best medical aid she steadily drooped, and two years after she had done her brave deed she died in the town of Bamborough where she had been born.

column2: Again a subscription was collected and a monument was erected in her honor.
column3: Again a subscription was collected and a monument was erected in her honor.

column2: Her father and mother lived to a ripe old age, reaping benefits from the money that Grace had left them.
column3: Her father and mother lived to a ripe old age, reaping benefits from the money that Grace had left them.

column2: Perhaps some of their descendants are still tending the light at the present day, but at all events the name of the Darlings has been made immortal by the bravery of this girl.
column3: Perhaps some of their descendants are still tending the light at the present day, but at all events the name of the Darlings has been made immortal by the bravery of this girl.
